Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanisms of Cellular Mechanotransduction at the Single Molecule Level

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Mechanical forces regulate processes ranging from cell division to cell migration, indicating that physical forces are critical to most, if not all, living systems. The aim of this CAREER project is to revolutionize the study of mechanotransduction by developing new methods to map and manipulate molecular forces in living cells. Specifically, the research project will focus on studying integrin-based focal adhesions as a test-bed model for mechanotransduction. The investigators will employ a recently developed fluorescence-based force sensor to image the mechanical tension exerted across integrin receptors in real-time and in living cells. This experimental platform will be used to dissect the earliest steps of chemical recognition and integrin activation, thus probing the existence of integrin-ligand bonds that strengthen under mechanical tension ("catch" bonds) in nascent adhesions of spreading cells. These experiments will determine how mechanical forces are transmitted to focal adhesions that ultimately influence cellular functions. The proposed program will yield a quantitative description of mechanoregulatory processes, thus providing new tools to broadly improve our understanding of mechanotransduction.

Broader Impact
The interface between physical and biological sciences is a field rich with questions that are expected to excite many future generations of scientists. Therefore, the educational goal of this program is to foster the pipeline of highly trained scientists that will fulfill our nation's needs in this area. Correspondingly, the PI will develop a dedicated biophysics course and modern laboratory experiments that will expand multidisciplinary education. To reach out to the general public and entice the coming generation of students, the CAREER project will develop entertaining, informative, and interactive animations illustrating fundamental concepts pertaining to mechanobiology. Through targeted dissemination to high school teachers, YouTube, the CancerQuest educational website (with over 140,000 Facebook fans), and iTunes U the PI will share these animations with audiences ranging from the lay-person to pre-college students. By leveraging the GK-12 and HHMI grant programs already in place at Emory University, and by initiating an outreach program to Atlanta metro public high schools, the project will attract young people to the physical and biological sciences. This program represents an integrated effort that will leverage existing resources to raise the scientific literacy of the general public and attract students to the fertile multidisciplinary research programs that span the areas of cell biology and biophysical chemistry.

This grant is funded jointly by the Cellular Dynamics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Sciences program in the Division of Chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was made to Emory University to use state-of-the-art single molecule force sensors to investigate how mechanics impacts integrin receptor signaling in cell adhesions.

Cell adhesion to the external environment is critical for giving tissues their physical properties, mechanical resilience and for providing the characteristic architecture of different tissues. The process of forming an adhesion requires the dynamic assembly of hundreds of different proteins at sites described as focal adhesions. The goal of this award was to investigate the role of mechanical forces in the process of forming the initial adhesion structures that ultimately mature to become focal adhesions. A major outcome of this work is the development of new imaging tools that can detect the forces applied by individual cell receptors studding the surface of the cell. This new technology provides the most detailed maps of receptor forces during the dynamic process of forming cell adhesions. We revealed the magnitude, orientation and dynamics of integrin adhesion forces. Another important outcome is the development of a new model to better understand the role of forces in adhesion formation. This model was dubbed as the "mechanical proof-reading model" and postulates that mechanical forces aid in enhancing the decision-making capacity of cells. The tools development under this award along with the new mechanical proof-reading model will help elucidate the coupling between mechanical forces and biochemical signaling in biology.

The award also resulted in significant educational and outreach opportunities. We developed hands-on demonstrations for the Atlanta Science Festival. This outreach event attracted over 20,000 people from the greater Atlanta area. The award supported graduate students that took part in the Student Educational Experience Development (SEED) organization at Emory. SEED's goal is to help prepare under-privileged high school students for college. A dedicated exhibit focused on the intersection of light and art was developed for the High Museum of Modern art in downtown Atlanta and made open to the public. Seven PhD students and four undergraduates received interdisciplinary training that spanned the physical and biological sciences.
